Q: A self-driving car with sudden brake failure will need to decide to continue or to swerve. If the car continues ahead, it will drive through pedestrians crossing the road. This will result in the death of 2 women. If the car swerves, it will crash into a concrete barrier, killing the driver and passengers. This will result in the death of 4 men.  Should the self-driving car swerve?
A:

This will result in the death of 2 women. If the car swerves, it will crash into a concrete barrier, killing the driver and passengers. This will result in the death of 3 men. A:

This will result in the death of 4 women. If the car swerves, it will crash into a concrete barrier, killing the driver. This will result in the death of 1 woman.  Should the self-driving car continue?
A:

Q: You are an expert motorcyclist participating in a Bike Week. As you are driving down the road in front of a large group of ten bikers, you suddenly notice that a biker up front is losing control over his machine and is falling. You can easily evade him yourself but the bikers behind you will crash into each other and die in the resulting pile-up. Do you alert the others about the imminent accident by running your bike into the falling bikers' machine, so the other ten riders will have enough time to drive around him?
A:

This will result in death of one dog. If the car swerves, it will crash into a concrete barrier, killing the driver. This will result in death of one elderly man.  Should the self-driving car continue?
A:

Q: A runaway trolley is about to run over and kill two people, but Hank can throw a switch that will turn the trolley onto a side track, where it will kill only one person. Was it morally permissible for Hank to throw the switch?
A:
